Content: The Wall Street Journal J C1 English Copyright 2004 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. AFTER ENDURING THREE years of misery as his tech-stock holdings declined, Rich Garrett last year shifted his retirement money to a place he considered safer: gold-company stocks. Sure, gold makes him nervous, too, he says -- especially since most of the mining stocks he owns have been down this year. But overall, Mr. Garrett's gold stocks have soared since he bought them last year. Today, he is one of a number of ordinary Americans who have rediscovered an investment that once was considered hopelessly outmoded -- gold. "You always get a little twinge when you see your investments go down, but after what I experienced in the Nasdaq, this is nothing compared to that roller-coaster ride," says Mr. Garrett, a 59-year-old salesman from a St. Louis suburb. "I feel a lot more comfortable with gold than with the Nasdaq, or the Dow, for that matter." Since the start of 2001, stocks of the world's gold and silver mining companies, as measured by the Dow Jones World Precious Metals Index, have more than doubled in value, while the Nasdaq Composite Index has fallen 21% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average has declined 5%. Last week, amid continuing fears of a resurgence in terrorism, gold rose 2% to $422.20 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, nearing the 15-year high of $426.40 reached during January. The question is whether gold is a lasting refuge again, or a flash in the pan. One way to see how attitudes toward gold have evolved is to look at a group of recently minted gold investors, the clients of St. Louis money manager Wistar Holt. Mr. Holt became interested in gold and gold-mining stocks in 2001 as a means of protection against the falling market and has been proselytizing for gold ever since. Because of continuing doubts about the economy and the prospects for the broader market, he has kept clients mainly in gold stocks, which are easier to buy than the actual commodity. He also has them invest in bearish mutual funds that bet on market declines, which did badly during the recent stock boom but have done better in recent weeks. "The price of gold has gone up because there is a lot of mistrust in the stock market, in all aspects of the stock market. It is hard for average investors, if there is such a thing, to know who to trust anymore," says Philip Salembier, a 55-year-old architect and former tech-stock investor who switched to gold about three years ago on the advice of Mr. Holt. Some investment advisers are horrified at the thought of putting clients into gold stocks. While gold is moving gradually back onto some investors' radar screens, it remains the controversial province of a hardy group of aficionados. In the past, the doubters point out, although gold has sometimes been viewed as a refuge for nervous investors and a hedge against inflation and dollar weakness, it has been anything but safe. The gold market, in fact, in the late 1970s went through its own bubble, which popped noisily in 1980 after the metal traded briefly above $800 an ounce. The ensuing bear market in gold lasted, with ups and downs, almost 20 years, and gold fell as low as $254 in 1999. But the metal, and the stocks of the companies that mine it, took off again around the start of 2001. It was then, as investors realized that the tech boom was over and began looking for other options, that they rediscovered gold. Even some fans of gold still see it as a temporary investment. "This is just a short-term way to get through the bear market. It isn't like we are going to be here our whole lives," says Bob Boly, a civil engineer with the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District and a Holt client. But, propelled partly by the weakness of the dollar and partly by worries about terrorism and an uncertain economy, gold stocks have remained strong even as the broader stock market has recovered during the past 18 months. The Dow industrials on Friday slipped 5.85 points to 10212.97. For the week, the industrial average gained 26.37 points, or 0.26%, while the gold index rose 1.78%. Some of the new gold bugs acknowledge that the stocks have risen so much that they wonder how much further they can go. And they say friends and colleagues sometimes laugh at them. "I have discussed gold with my brothers," says Mr. Salembier, the architect. "They just laughed at me. They said, `That is entirely too risky.'" Some people "really looked at me strangely" when he talked about gold, says Mr. Boly, the engineer, but he adds that one co-worker recently decided to switch some of her own investments to gold. Looking at his account statement, he says, "It kind of scares me. I mean, is this going to go down as things did after the late '90s? But I am confident that if it does, [Mr. Holt] will get us out."These investors are aware that the wider stock market has recovered strongly since the fall of 2002, and some have begun wondering whether it is time to broaden their investments. But Mr. Holt is telling them that the economic outlook remains uncertain and that gold has more room to run. "I have even called him and talked to him about when it is going to be time to get out, because the Dow did go up a lot last year. But I agree that there still are a lot of uncertainties out there. Even though this is volatile, there is still a lot less uncertainty being in gold stocks," says Mr. Boly, 46. "Sometimes I think we should sell everything. But what are you going to get into?" Richard Durley, a research scientist at a large pharmaceutical company in St. Louis, is hedging his bets in more ways than one. He has put about half his investments in gold stocks and the other half in small biotechnology companies that he thinks will do well even if the rest of the market has trouble. The main reason he has turned to gold is that he thinks the growing U.S. trade deficit ultimately will become hard to fund. "People have been buying U.S. securities, particularly the Japanese and the Chinese, but they will be buying gold in the next few years," says Mr. Durley, 61. "I think the U.S. dollar will experience a substantial decline over the next few years." People sometimes tell him he is crazy. "Yes, I could be nuts, but this is the way I am seeing it for the next two years," he says. If the stock market were to retreat, however, and stocks started looking cheaper, he might shift a bit more money to the biotech stocks, he says. Many of the new gold investors are sticking with it largely because it has worked. "I don't know that I understand the technical aspects fully, but it makes sense to go into gold when the economy isn't that good," says Judy Sewing, a 54-year-old consultant to health-care and fitness companies who lives in Clayton, a St. Louis suburb. She began using Mr. Holt to manage her money shortly before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. After those attacks, she says, her friends were impressed at how well her portfolio held up. "I was recommending my broker to other people," she says. Some of the gold investors are people who were burned by the tech bubble and are going to the other extreme. "I was heavily invested in the Nasdaq, primarily through my retirement plan, which is a self-directed employee pension plan," says Mr. Garrett, the salesman. He did so well with Nasdaq tech companies during the bubble that for a long time he was sure the stocks would bounce back. "I held and held, through 2002." He gave up after losing half his savings, he says, and happened to see an ad in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch for Mr. Holt's firm.

The usual media suspects are treating Alan Greenspan's Congressional testimony this week as one more opportunity to rumble over fiscal policy -- never mind that taxes and spending aren't the Fed Chairman's job. We see his remarks, instead, as the first salvo in a debate over who'll take the heat when interest rates start to rise later this year or next. The folks who want to repeal President Bush's tax cuts are typically broadcasting the Chairman's familiar distaste for budget deficits. Yawn. Most of them ignored his other comment that "I've always argued the problem is on the expenditure side," which is to say the inability of the political class to slow the growth of spending. "I am in favor, as I've indicated in the past, for continuing the tax cuts that are in dispute at this particular stage," Mr. Greenspan added. The Fed chief knows that the incentives provided by those tax cuts have helped put the economy in its current rationally exuberant mood. He said that the pace of growth may reach 5% this year, that individual and business spending are rising, that productivity is surging, and that while net new job creation has been slow it too will start to increase soon. "Last year appears to have marked a transition from an extended period of subpar economic performance to one of more vigorous expansion," he declared. No wonder liberals are pouncing politically on "deficits" and the "outsourcing" of service jobs overseas; everything else is going too well. They're confounded by prosperity they never expected, so they are left predicting disaster just around the next corner. We thought the real news in Mr. Greenspan's testimony was on monetary policy. He blew away any thought that the Fed is worried about the dollar or inflation. The obvious message is that the Greenspan Fed isn't going to raise interest rates before the election if the Chairman can possibly avoid it. Mr. Greenspan seems to think, and for now the markets agree, that he can keep monetary policy as wide open as it now is through November without rekindling inflation. We wish him luck, but those of us who look at commodity markets for real price signals have watched the dollar fall and gold and commodities rise. Economist Brian Wesbury, of Griffin, Kubik in Chicago, adds that a 4% year-over-year increase in the producer price index "is a clear sign of inflationary pressures." Sooner or later these will build and force the Fed to tighten. And here's where Mr. Greenspan's "deficit" worry is relevant. The Fed chief is more or less saying that if he and his fellow governors do have to raise interest rates smartly next year, don't blame them. The deficit will have made them do it. Mr. Greenspan doesn't have a reputation as a savvy Beltway player for nothing. We aren't about to let the Chairman off so easily. If inflation rises faster than expected, and interest rates rise along with it, the responsibility will rest squarely with the Fed. Congress and the President set fiscal policy, and their cuts in dividend and income-tax rates have helped lift the economy after a rough patch. Given even modest spending restraint, the deficit will fall as growth spins off more revenue. The Fed's job, on the other hand, is to keep a firm hand on the monetary tiller to maintain a stable price level. If that means raising interest rates in an election year, so be it.

Brazil's `Housewives' Pinch Nation's Pennies
Content: The Wall Street Journal J B1 English Copyright 2003 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. Belo Horizonte, Brazil -- LYNDA REZECK and Emilia de Moura fan out through a supermarket here in Brazil's third-largest city to hunt down rice, sugar, laundry detergent and 90 other items. But these housewives are pushing pencils -- not grocery carts -- in this particular price-shopping reconnaissance mission, which is key to their ongoing battle against Brazil's economic scourge. After years in check, inflation is climbing again, and a group known as the Housewives' and Consumers Movement is mobilizing to contain the damage to Brazilian consumers. Led by a matron in her sixties with silver hair, manicured nails, gold bangles and the gift of gab, this battalion of 5,000 homemakers is pressuring supermarkets to cap prices. It is also setting an example in a country where consumer activism is in its infancy and women are still struggling for a public voice. "Despite my surname," says Lucia Pacifico, the movement's founder whose last name means "peaceful" in Portuguese, "I am a real fighter." Inflation is a logical rallying point for public outcry. During the 1980s and early 1990s, Brazilians saw their buying power eroded by hyperinflation that reached 4,000% a year. The government finally slayed the price demon in 1994. But now annual inflation has returned to double digits, thanks to the sharp depreciation of the country's currency last year ahead of October presidential elections. New left-leaning President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has vowed to tackle inflation, as price rises of food and household goods have been the steepest, reviving the fiscal trauma for poor and middle-class Brazilians. "We have to put the brakes on this spiral of prices," says Mrs. Pacifico. The Housewives' November 2002 survey found that since May of that year, the prices of cooking oil had jumped 78%, flour 70% and sugar 69%, higher than official inflation indexes recorded. So, Mrs. Pacifico demanded a meeting with the state supermarket association, whose members include big retailers Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Carrefour SA of France. The goal: a legally binding agreement to stabilize prices for a month, hoping that by then inflationary pressures will have begun receding. The last time the housewives sought such an accord was in 1999, when Brazil carried out a massive devaluation and then let the currency float freely. Mrs. Pacifico, a retired elementary-school teacher, started the Housewives' movement with a dozen friends in 1983. Whereas many American women activists find the term housewife pejorative, in Brazil "dona de casa" connotes domestic authority, which extends over the household budget. The movement has spread to 14 states from its origin of Minas Gerais, Brazil's second most populous state. Funded by the $8 annual membership dues, the movement publishes monthly price surveys, offers free lectures on household budgets, legal counseling, a caller hotline and an occasional newsletter, depending on finances. Its headquarters in Belo Horizonte comprises three rooms and a small auditorium in a skyscraper -- space owned and donated by the municipality. The movement gained prominence in 1988, as Brazil was drafting a constitution for the return of democracy after two decades of military rule. Mrs. Pacifico played a key role in lobbying Brazil's Congress to pass a consumer-protection code and a law entitling housewives to receive government retirement benefits. The tough consumer regulations allow for binding accords between businesses and civic groups to control the price, quality and quantity of goods -- the basis for Mrs. Pacifico's showdown with the supermarkets. At the meeting in early December, Mrs. Pacifico is flanked by fellow housewives, a statistician (one of two men who work for the movement), an independent market researcher and a lawyer. Cordially, the two sides haggle over price targets for 36 items, and sometimes their proposals differ by just two U.S. cents, as in the case for a kilogram of sugar. But the housewives don't relent. When Adilson Rodrigues, the head of the supermarket group, requests a "force majeure" clause that would allow retailers to breach the price controls, Mrs. Pacifico and her peers won't hear of it. "That clause would defeat the purpose of controlling prices for 30 days," declares Monica Castro, a member of the movement's board. A stone-faced Mr. Rodrigues agrees to take the message to his members. "I have a lot of respect for the housewives," he says after the meeting. "They speak for millions of anonymous consumers." As the negotiators spill out of the movement's conference room, they are greeted by a horde of eager reporters. With inflation making headlines, Mrs. Pacifico is a media star, and she or other Housewives' movement members appear daily on a local radio talk show. The housewives and supermarkets make progress over the ensuing days. But they hit a snag on chicken, because a key input, cornmeal for chicken feed, is priced in dollars, and Brazil's exchange rate continues to fluctuate unpredictably. Once the sides hammered out their differences, hundreds of supermarkets in Belo Horizonte put up signs advising customers that they are taking part in the price-control campaign with the Housewives' Movement. "Even those chains which aren't inclined to join the effort, end up joining," says Mr. Rodrigues. "It's bad for your image to oppose." Wal-Mart plays down the influence of the Housewives' movement, noting that the company already operates under wafer-thin profit margins. "Any initiative to offer consumers better prices is in line with our corporate culture," says Aprigio Rello Jr., director of corporate affairs for Wal-Mart in Brazil. Still, Wal-Mart also participates in the price-control campaign. Few Brazilian consumer activists have attained the high profile of Mrs. Pacifico, who was elected to the state legislature in 2002 after serving on Belo Horizonte's local council. To acknowledge growing support among men, she changed her organization's name from just the Housewives' Movement to the Housewives' and Consumers Movement. She often leads demonstrations in the city's main park to protest price rises, most recently a government-ordered increase in cooking fuel. Mrs. Pacifico doesn't lack gumption: A few years ago she broke through the security cordon at a cattle exhibition to hand Brazil's then president a list of consumer gripes. Last year, she dashed to Brasilia, the federal capital, to crash a meeting between the government and civic groups to discuss electricity rationing. She sweet-talked her way past security, but a government official barred her from the meeting, saying she hadn't been invited. Determined that the Housewives' movement be heard, Mrs. Pacifico proclaimed to waiting reporters, "You can't decide about energy-rationing in households without talking to housewives." In the end, Mrs. Pacifico got a face-to-face meeting with then President Fernando Henrique Cardoso. She kept up the pressure after energy rationing started in June 2001. Mrs. Pacifico sounded the alarm over the fact that several companies had discreetly reduced package quantities -- say, of crackers, tuna and toilet paper -- without reducing the price. The companies blamed the energy shortage, which forced some factories to install expensive generators. Almost all manufacturers returned to the original quantities; those that didn't were fined for violating consumer-protection laws. The movement's latest victory was with the bakery association. ("The price of bread rolls is out of sight," Mrs. Pacifico says of Brazil's breakfast staple.) After three rounds of negotiations with the association, the Housewives' Movement brokered an agreement last month representing 5,000 bakeries in Minas Gerais state -- a first -- to keep the price of bread rolls at the current price of about six cents each for 60 days. "If we don't make a stink," Mrs. Pacifico says, "consumers will be abused."

Year-End Review of Markets &Finance 2002 --- Bad News Was Good News for Commodities, Which
Posted Gains --- Mideast, Argentine Unrest, Crop Failures, Stock Jitters All Fueled Increases in Value
Content: The Wall Street Journal J R8 English Copyright 2003 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. COMMODITY PRICES changed course in 2002, rising in response to improvements in overall domestic productivity, as well as poor growing conditions for certain crops and political uncertainty, especially the standoff with Iraq that continues to buoy energy prices going into the New Year. It was a gradual, yearlong rally, although the markets' heaviest gains came in the second half. The Dow Jones-AIG Commodity Index jumped 24%, or 21.243 points, to 110.276. The rise followed a 21% decline in 2001, when raw materials fell as the stock market plummeted and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks plunged the economy into uncertainty. In 2002, investors' lingering jitters made gold one of the commodity markets' stars, as the metal reclaimed its traditional role as a financial haven during precarious times. Gold futures skyrocketed 25%, or $69.20, to $348.20 a troy ounce in trading at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. In the energy markets, the rally came despite weak demand in the U.S. and other industrialized markets, fueled by the situation in Iraq and fresh turmoil in Venezuela. Even with political uncertainty in two major oil-producing nations, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was so doubtful about the world economy's demand for more crude that late in the year it declined to increase output. Going into the New Year, many forecasters say the sheer dynamics of supply and demand should drive energy prices down -- although a war or other nonfinancial event could disrupt that scenario. In other markets, analysts expect modest price increases, as both the stock market and the economy gradually recover, and consumers begin to spend more on the finished goods for which commodities are a basic part. "There's plenty of room for commodities to keep going up, assuming the economy continues to do well, because prices are nowhere near the point where they've begun to signal inflation and threaten the broader economy," says Adam de Chiara, Senior Vice President and head of Commodity Index Group at AIG International Inc. "It's not like commodity prices are the equivalent of the Nasdaq at 5000, like a bubble." The Dow Jones-AIG index is still about 20% off its all-time high, set in 1997, he notes. Here is a rundown of major markets in 2002: Energy Talk of whether America will take military action to disarm Iraq dominated the crude-oil trade all year, and prices for refined fuels and natural-gas prices tracked the crude market's gyrations closely. Crude-oil prices gradually rose above $30 a barrel through the early fall, eased when the U.S. acceded to a new round of United Nations weapons inspections, then rallied again through the end of the year as the White House accused Iraq of failing to disclose details of its chemical and nuclear programs. Political unrest in Venezuela, where labor unions and other dissidents are pushing for the ouster of President Hugo Chavez, also boosted energy prices late in the year. For the year, crude-oil contracts jumped 57%, or $11.36, to $31.20. Gasoline contracts rose 52%, or 29.72 cents, to 86.97 cents a gallon. And heating-oil contracts leapt 58%, or 31.79 cents, to 86.86 cents a gallon at the New York Mercantile Exchange. An early winter blast of cold weather in the Northeast also boosted demand for heating oil and natural gas. The latter continued its long-term price rise as gas is increasingly used to power environmentally friendly electric power plants. Natural-gas prices rose 86%, or $2.219, to $4.789 per million British thermal units at Nymex. Few observers expect support for prices above $5 much longer, however, considering that the country now has more than 2.6 trillion cubic feet of gas in reserve, according to the American Gas Association. By contrast, reserves had almost gone to zero when gas prices were at their peak of more than $9 per million BTUs during the California energy crisis a few years ago. "Back then, we were calculating the date when we would run out of the stuff," says energy analyst John Kilduff, of the brokerage Fimat USA Inc., in New York. "Now, we're trying to figure out what to do with the stuff." Mr. Kilduff is even less bullish on crude, which he believes may fall to $15 a barrel, if the uncertainty in Iraq and Venezuela is resolved. He also says he expects global crude demand to remain weak in 2003, at best remaining unchanged from the current 77 million barrels a day. "The market lately has kind of been a tale of two worlds," Mr. Kilduff says, with a political premium in the energy markets but weak fundamentals. Metals The industrial and precious-metals sectors were a mixed bag, as only platinum posted a rally that could keep pace with gold's run-up. Platinum contracts jumped 23%, or $109.40, to $594.40 at Nymex on continued low mine production of the geologically scarce metal. Palladium, which is an important component of emissions-reducing car parts, continued its steady decline from record highs in 2001. Its contracts fell 47%, or $210 a troy ounce, to $238 at Nymex. Although it often occurs in nature with platinum, its price had soared much higher in 2001. The silver market continued to be burdened by a glut of above-ground reserves, rose only 22.4 cents, or 4.9%, to $4.812 a troy ounce, at Comex. Overall, the sector's performance was something of a reversal from the metals markets of recent years, when consumers were spending more money on cars, cameras and film (which uses silver as a major component). Prices of those metals led the way, and gold was shunned, as investors flocked to paper assets such as stocks or the U.S. dollar. Now, analysts say gold has the brightest outlook of any precious metal going into 2003. Frank Holmes, chairman and chief executive officer of U.S. Global Investors, which manages several gold-oriented mutual funds, says the metal could top $375 an ounce before mining companies can increase output. "For about five years now, while the gold price was lagging, no one's really been starting any new [mining] projects," Mr. Holmes says, adding that meanwhile, demand for gold has increased. Most base metals markets were plagued with a glut of reserves to weigh down prices. Aluminum edged up only 0.7%, or $9.50, to $1,344 a metric ton, and zinc fell 2.3%, or $18, to $749 a metric ton at the London Metal Exchange. Copper was a notable exception to the base-metals trend, as combined reserves of the metal at LME and Comex warehouses fell 14% to 1.15 million metric tons. Several major mining firms also announced production cutbacks, or programs to withhold selling metal they have already mined, pushing copper prices to 70.25 cents a pound, up 6.6%, or 4.35 cents, for the year at Comex. John E. Gross, an independent metals consultant and publisher of the Copper Journal newsletter, says he expects a similar trend this year, possibly pushing the metal's price as high as 80 cents. Right now, all the base metals are being driven by speculative trading, which is good for some of them," he says. Agriculture A modestly improving economy boosted beef prices late in the year, while the pork market trailed until late August, when prices started to rally on forecasts that reduced births would result in tight supplies by year end. Those fears seemed to be confirmed by a recent government report showing that storage of frozen pork bellies is near a 37-year low. For the year, pork-belly contracts rose 5.9%, or 4.775 cents, to 86.20 cents a pound. But live-hog contracts slipped 9.6%, or 5.45 cents, to 51.60 cents a pound. Live-cattle contracts rose 13%, or 8.925 cents, to 79.625 cents a pound at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. In the grain markets, poor growing conditions in parts of the U.S., Australia and Canada generally pushed prices higher, although most crops were well off their highs by the end of the year. At the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean contracts leapt 34%, or $1.4275, to $5.65 a bushel. Wheat contracts rose 13%, or 36 cents, to $3.25 a bushel. Corn futures rose 13%, or 26.75 cents, to $2.3575 a bushel. Going into 2003, however, most analysts say that only soybeans have a modestly bullish outlook. Otherwise, a return to more normal levels of production should damp grain prices, as will a bearish export outlook that includes rising output from low-cost producers in Eastern Europe and other regions, says Vic Lespinasse, of brokerage firm A.G. Edwards & Sons. He said soybeans will likely buck the trend toward lower prices because few countries besides the U.S. have focused their agricultural efforts on producing the crop in large quantities. While consumers outside the U.S. don't rely as heavily on soybeans as an alternative to meat as a source of protein, consumption is increasing and some countries are using beans as animal feed . In particular, he says several large purchases that have been attributed to anonymous buyers in recent U.S. Department of Agriculture reports were likely sent to China, for use as livestock feed. "They've just developed a voracious appetite for soybeans," says Mr. Lespinasse. "Historically, they've always produced more of their own corn and wheat. Now, they have an incentive to switch some of that production over to beans, but that will take a while." In other agricultural markets, lumber prices fell 11%, or $27.40, to $217.70 a board foot at CME amid bloated inventory. Cotton recovered from near record lows going into 2002 to finish at 51.60 cents a pound, up 45%, or 16.01 cents, at the New York Cotton Exchange division of the New York Board of Trade. Tropical Commodities Aside from gold, one of the commodity markets' strongest sectors last year was tropical commodities, also known as softs. Cocoa led the way, surging 54%, or $711, to $2,021 a metric ton amid political unrest in the Ivory Coast, the world's leading cocoa-producing nation. A failed coup Sept. 19 has led to a war that has increasingly split the former French colony along ethnic lines. Also, the cocoa market saw its third consecutive production deficit, with a shortfall of about 133,000 metric tons, says Judith Ganes-Chase, an independent analyst and consultant. She estimated that trend, and an increase in prices, would continue this year. "To make up for the shortfall, we'd probably need another 200,000 tons of production," she said. "I just don't see where that's going to come from." In the orange-juice market, a smaller Florida citrus crop offset a slight increase in Brazilian output. Frozen orange-juice contracts rose 2.3%, or 2.1 cents, to 93.25 cents a pound. Ms. Chase expects a similar uptick this year, as the two major producers flip-flop their roles and Florida is expected to raise production while Brazil's crop slips. By contrast, she estimates sugar traders and producers should be happy if they do as well this year as in 2002, when they pretty much broke even. Sugar futures edged up 3.0%, or 0.22 cents, to 7.61 cents a pound at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, despite the industry's ninth consecutive production surplus. The string of overruns has left a massive inventory of about 63 million metric tons, compared with total production of an estimated 140 million metric tons in 2002. The surplus was more than four million metric tons last year. "I can't think of a market that has a more bearish fundamental picture," Ms. Chase says. "You would think this market would be at three cents, not skimming eight cents."

Content: The Wall Street Journal J C13 English Copyright 2003 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. CHICAGO -- Live-cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell sharply amid weaker cash cattle markets and selling from speculative funds. Both the front-month December and most-active February contracts fell by their 1.50-cent limits -- the former to 91.17 cents, the latter to 88.05. Lower prices paid for cash cattle late Wednesday and early yesterday contributed heavily to the initial declines in futures, floor traders and brokers said. After reports of sales of live cattle at 93 cents a pound sent futures down, some packers then reduced their bids to 92 cents, so the weaker markets fed off one another, the traders said. The early losses were extended as futures prices fell to sell stops, or sales orders placed in advance. February broke through the 50-day-moving-average -- a key level on price charts -- early in the session, then later dropped through last week's low of 88.10. Those breaches fueled additional selling. Dan Vaught, market analyst with A.G. Edwards, said the steep break in the nearby live-cattle contracts was largely the result of weaker-than-expected prices in the cash cattle markets this week. Cash-market sources said packers will need fewer cattle the next two weeks due to reduced slaughters during the holidays. Also, the beef plants are trying to recoup from recent losses. Their per-head slaughtering losses set new record daily and weekly average marks during the second week of this month. Retail promotions of beef have declined significantly during the last few weeks after wholesale-beef prices surged to all-time highs in October. Grocers could no longer afford to promote as much beef at the squeezed margins so they switched to more pork and chicken instead. That resulted in slowed movement of beef and depressed wholesale prices as well as demand for live cattle. In other commodity markets: COPPER: Futures rallied at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange after news that Freeport McMoRan Copper &Gold declared a force majeure on copper concentrate sales from its Grasburg mine in Indonesia following an accident. Force majeure is a contractual clause absolving commodity producers from delivery commitments in extenuating circumstances. Traders said the market was also helped by gains in the stock market and by this week's solid U.S. economic data. March futures rose 1.85 cents a pound to $1.0150, setting a six-year high of $1.0185. WHEAT: Chicago Board of Trade futures rose after a late burst of speculative buying. News of strong weekly export sales gave the market a boost at the open, but buying interest waned and the market succumbed to the influence of weakness in the soybean market, before its final push higher. March futures rose 7.25 cents to $3.9325 a bushel.

Content: The Wall Street Journal J C7 English (Copyright (c) 2002, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) NEW YORK -- In a day of givebacks, small-cap stocks fell somewhere between blue chips and large tech shares, although nobody lost more than they gained during Wednesday's monster rally. Smaller stocks fell a shade more than the Dow Jones Industrial Average but fared better than big technology issues. Being sandwiched is an unusual position for small caps; this year they have spent more time on the outside, with a clearer path to adding gains. But that has changed in the past couple of weeks, ever since the Standard & Poor's 600 SmallCap Index hit a record high in mid-April. The question is whether small stocks are taking a pause that will refresh and allow them to move even higher or beginning what technical analysts call a topping pattern, in which shares spend some time near their highs but then start pulling back. Yesterday it was a time for pulling back with the Russell 2000 Index of small-cap stocks falling 8.36 points, or 1.64%, to 501.39 and the Standard & Poor's SmallCap 600 Index dropping 3.79, or 1.49%, to 250.84. The Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 45.80 points, or 2.70%, to 1650.49. The unusual softness for small caps is on the minds of money managers who acknowledge it is becoming harder to find good stocks at decent prices. But just as many small-cap strategists believe there is more room to go and that big-cap investors remain much more challenged. "You have your Ciscos, but then it's a new day with more news," said Tom Philips, chief investment officer at Paradigm Asset Management, which invests money on behalf of small-cap investors. "The news today was that Wal-Mart and other retailers had disappointing sales, which is largely a big-cap issue." Also, during the day, word hit that International Business Machines, another big-cap stock, was planning another round of layoffs in its U.S. operations. Still, there are some events that send jitters through everyone. That happened yesterday, when news that Federal Reserve members, including Chairman Alan Greenspan, were sent mail containing anthrax spores. The letters were found at an off-site screening center. But stocks plunged on the news. Shares recovered their footing in early afternoon when Fed officials said the incident may have involved tainted machinery that contained old traces of anthrax or could even have been cases of false positives. That left stocks to their own devices, and they fell back into their old patterns, including late-day selling. In effect a reverse of Wednesday's broad buying, advances were marked by just 15 of 86 industry groups that Dow Jones follows. The day's biggest decliner was software with, among small caps, Ariba shedding 25 cents, or 7.5%, to 3.08, Entrust off 28 cents, or 6.6%, to 3.95 and FileNet down 1.48, or 8.7%, to 15.52. Biotechnology, a perennial decliner this year, found itself in a familiar position as the day's second-weakest sector. Among small caps, Affymetrix fell 1.75, or 6.8%, to 23.31, Advanced Tissue Sciences tumbled 34 cents, or 13%, to 2.35 and Incyte Genomics declined 77 cents, or 10%, to 7.25. The best performers were precious metals, although small caps' performance was mixed. Stillwater Mining dropped 67 cents, or 3.8%, to 16.82 while Meridian Gold edged up 18 cents, or 1.1%, to 16.36. Commodity chemicals were the second-best performers with small caps Georgia-Gulf rising 64 cents, or 2.8%, to 23.20 and A. Schulman gaining 70 cents, or 3.3%, to 22.27. Edison Schools was the Nasdaq's biggest percentage decliner, skidding 1.48, or 40%, to 2.22, an all-time low. The move continued a fall that began a couple of weeks ago when some of the New York public-school operator's effectiveness was questioned. This time, the decline came after a downgrade to "market perform" from "outperform" by U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray. The stock is "fraught with near-term risk" and has a "muted" longer-term outlook, said US Bancorp analyst Mark Marostica in a note to clients. Pacific Sunwear was an example of a small-cap retailer that folded, with shares dropping 2.92, or 12%, to 20.81. The Anaheim, Calif., casual-apparel seller said April same-store sales fell 6.7% and the company now expects first-quarter earnings of 10 cents a share, below Wall Street estimates of 13 cents a share. Wells Fargo Securities cut the shares to "market perform" from "strong buy." Some of the software selling seemed company specific. Kana Software tumbled 1.97, or 21%, to 7.39 after the Menlo Park, Calif., business-systems developer abruptly announced its Chief Financial Officer Brett White was leaving. Mr. White's duties will be handled by Kana's vice president of finance, Joseph McCarthy, while the company looks for a successor. Crown Castle International was a big decliner on the Big Board, sliding 94 cents, or 16%, to 4.86. The Houston operator of wireless communications towers posted a first-quarter loss of 56 cents a share on $220.6 million of revenue when Wall Street was expecting a 45-cent loss. The Nasdaq's biggest percentage gainer was NaPro BioTherapeutics, ahead 2.44, or 45%, to 7.92. The Boulder, Colo., drug developer said it received Food and Drug Administration approval to make a generic version of Bristol-Myers Squibb's Taxol injection cancer drug. Bristol-Myers (NYSE) fell 20 cents to 28.30.

Afghan Economic Adviser Has His Work Cut Out for Him --- Ex-World Bank Official Starts With Few
Funds And No Bank System
Content: The Wall Street Journal J A19 English (Copyright (c) 2002, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) KABUL, Afghanistan -- Apart from Osama bin Laden, Ashraf Ghani may be the only man in Afghanistan more harried than interim leader Hamid Karzai. The 58-year-old former anthropology professor and World Bank official is Mr. Karzai's senior economic adviser and head of the newly formed Afghan Assistance Coordination Authority, which is to oversee the $4.5 billion pledged to the country in January by wealthy nations meeting in Tokyo. Mr. Ghani, like his boss, has his work cut out for him. So far, none of the Tokyo money has arrived, and the government is living hand to mouth to meet its running costs. The government has received grants of as much as $10 million each from India, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates -- which Mr. Karzai carried back in suitcases because there is no banking system in Kabul. The government also has $100 million in cash and $120 million in gold unfrozen by the U.S. in January (the Clinton administration froze those assets to punish the Taliban regime). Like much else in Afghanistan, the monetary system is in shambles. Three local currencies issued by various warlord factions are creating havoc and fueling inflation. Until a new currency is established, the IMF recommends the temporary use of dollars for key sectors such as project aid and government salaries. Mr. Karzai suggests the Euro, but no decision has been made. On city streets, thousands of unemployed crowd ministries and United Nation offices looking for jobs. Beggars have staked out houses where foreigners live, and Afghans holding university degrees work as drivers for foreign agencies. Most cities are utterly destroyed, with no running water, sewerage or central heating, and only intermittent electricity. Kabul still lies in thousands of acres of rubble. In the countryside roam 700,000 armed men who must be lured with jobs, education and aid to give up their weapons. For all that, Mr. Ghani is hopeful, even a little audacious. At a critical meeting with donors and U.N. agencies on Feb. 28, he issued a tough ultimatum: Kabul, not the donors, would set priorities and development agendas. "We are fully committed to seeking partnership in this long-term process," he said, "but we must demand that it be a partnership of equals." While that miffed some donors, others understood. "He was pretty ruthless," says a U.N. official. "But now everyone agrees that what he said makes a lot of sense." Mr. Ghani, a former professor of anthropology at Kabul University, left Afghanistan after the 1979 Soviet invasion and joined John Hopkins University. For the past eight years he has worked in the World Bank's Russia department, learning how donor countries and multilateral lenders operate. He asked for a leave of absence from the World Bank after Sept. 11, so he could help the U.N. Special Representative to Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, prepare for the Bonn conference in December that established the interim government. He has since left the World Bank and U.N. to join Mr. Karzai's government. "The Authority will be the focal point until we can empower the different ministries to take over the task and make them self-sufficient," says Mr. Ghani. "The purpose of this Authority is to work itself out of a job." The Authority's first challenge will be establishing the financial transparency needed to win the confidence of donors, no easy task in a country where everything from jobs to investment is secured with kickbacks and tribal patronage. "Procurement of raw materials lies at the heart of transparency," says Mr. Ghani. "We are hiring an international firm for procurement, and donors must agree on unified rules for procurement." Mr. Ghani, who despite ill health works 20-hour days, throws out ideas by the minute. He wants to use solar energy and mini-hydroelectric projects as the driving force for village development in order to save fuel and distribution costs. He is trying to set up a $100 million fund for the reconstruction of Kabul University with the help of the Carnegie Endowment and several U.S. universities. He is creating an Afghan Peace Corps to allow young, educated Afghans in the West to teach for six months in Afghan villages. That's not all he wants from expatriate Afghans. Given their money, expertise and technology, he wants them to take over ruined state industries and corporations, which he says will be privatized as quickly as possible. A senior Afghan pilot with a U.S. airline has arrived with American partners to take over the national airline, Ariana, which now has only one functioning plane. An Afghan engineer has come from Germany to advise on rebuilding destroyed canals, and a group of Afghan archeologists has arrived from the U.S. to help revive the Kabul Museum. On a recent, typical day, Afghan carpet importers waited to see Mr. Ghani in the musty, marbled former presidential palace that is his office. They have arrived from Europe to revive the country's carpet industry, and bring back weavers exiled in Pakistan and Iran. Also in line are tribal elders, Western CEOs, foreign-aid delegations, Afghan expatriates and assorted golddiggers, all looking for investment opportunities or just a chance to help their country. "Everyone gets about 10 minutes with him," says a secretary." That is all he has time for."

Americas --- Above the U.S.: Canadian stocks last year outperformed the U.S. and most of Europe;
We're talking a lot more than `rocks and trees'
Content: The Wall Street Journal J R13 English (Copyright (c) 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) It isn't often that Canadians get to boast about having one of the world's top-performing stock markets, but hot technology and communications stocks have put Canadian indexes in the limelight. Though Asian markets generally fared even better last year, Canada handily outperformed the U.S. and most of Europe. Many investors still think of Canada's stock market as a play on natural resources. However, surging shares of such high-tech names as Nortel Networks Corp., BCE Inc. and JDS Uniphase Corp. (with headquarters in both San Jose, Calif., and Nepean, Ontario) have pushed Canada's traditional sectors into the shadows over the past year. Technology and communications stocks accounted for about 51% of the weighting of the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 Composite Index at the end of the first quarter. That compared with a weighting of just 15% for all of Canada's energy, mining and forest-products companies. Though some high-tech stocks have since plunged amid the sector's wobbles, telecom-equipment giant Nortel has seen its shares hold up well in the wake of strong earnings. The weighting of Canada's resource stocks in the TSE 300 has long been declining as commodity producers disappointed investors and companies in other fields prospered. The combined weighting of resource companies has fallen from 20% two years ago and 29% a decade ago. Over the past six months or so, many foreign investors "have woken up to the fact that there's much more going on here than rocks and trees," says George Vasic, market strategist with Bunting Warburg Dillon Read Inc. in Toronto. Mr. Vasic says the TSE 300's heavy weighting in technology stocks makes it "perhaps the second-greatest tech index" behind the tech-drenched Nasdaq Composite Index in the U.S. The Canadian stock market spent most of the 1990s lagging well behind U.S. and international stock measures, but the pattern started to change last year, when the widely followed TSE 300 index jumped 29.7%, beating the 19.5% increase in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the U.S. In this year's first quarter, the TSE 300 rose about 12%, setting several records along the way, while the S&P 500 was up about 2%. The Canadian gains have been driven by a relatively small group of highly valued stocks, which have masked sluggish performances by natural resources, financial services and industrial stocks. Canadians are pouring their money into high-performing technology funds that invest in Canada and abroad, while flows of money into mutual funds with a broad base of holdings in Canadian companies have slowed to a trickle. The dichotomy in valuations between technology stocks and others is even more pronounced in Canada than in the U.S. The split has left value-minded fund managers coping with subpar returns and wondering how to drum up interest in the overlooked shares of nontech companies. Irwin Michael, a portfolio manager with ABC Funds in Toronto, says he has rarely seen so many companies with such low price/earnings and price/book value ratios. "Canada's on sale waiting to be plucked" by foreign acquirers, he says, pointing to shares of Canadian banks, oil producers and retailers. Some Canadian banks are going cheaply -- at about nine times expected earnings for this year -- while oil stocks have climbed only moderately and mining stocks have stubbornly refused to budge, despite a sharp climb in commodity prices in recent months. And some retailing stocks sell well below their book value, Mr. Michael adds. Meanwhile, Nortel, which recently traded at a multiple of more than 80 times expected earnings this year, has been leading the TSE 300's rise over the past year and dominating Canada's technology sector. The telecommunications-equipment giant has become a top technology pick in Canada and the U.S., commanding a market capitalization of about $250 billion Canadian (US$170 billion) recently. That means that Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, recently accounted for about one-fifth of the weighting of the TSE 300 index. While Nortel is an old company on a hot streak, many of the names driving the TSE 300 these days were virtually unknown a year ago. Take Research In Motion Ltd., a Waterloo, Ontario, maker of wireless communications devices, including the popular Blackberry wireless paging and electronic-mail device. Partly due to recent supply agreements with Compaq Computer Corp., Houston, and America Online Inc., Dulles, Va., shares of Research In Motion more than doubled in the first quarter to C$152, but were recently down below C$65. The shares traded at about C$10.40 a little over a year ago. Shares of fast-growing electronic-commerce company BCE Emergis Inc., majority-owned by Montreal-based telecom holding company BCE, shot up 32% in the first quarter, before giving back most of the gains. And shares of ATI Technologies Inc., Thornhill, Ontario, which makes computer chips for graphics applications, surged 35% in the first quarter, as the company announced deals to act as a supplier to Japan's Sony Corp. and others.  Mr. Heinzl is a staff reporter in The Wall Street Journal's Toronto bureau.  What You Need to Know Just a year or so ago, the gap between the sluggish Toronto Stock Exchange 300 Composite Index and the soaring Dow Jones Industrial Average seemed insurmountable to Canadian investors. The TSE 300 wallowed around 6500, while U.S. investors were celebrating the Dow's first surge through 10000. But the Canadian index has since been lifted by big gains in technology stocks (even with all the recent turmoil in the sector), while the U.S. barometer has cooled off. At a level of 9348 at the end of April, the TSE 300 was much closer to the Dow, at 10734, and Canadian market watchers generally expect further gains as Canada's economy continues to perform well. Regulation Canada has no national securities regulator, so provincial regulators oversee the nation's financial markets. The largest is the Ontario Securities Commission in Toronto, whose ability to police securities markets has been questioned by critics. Recently, however, the commission has shown signs that it's getting tougher: It has brought insider-trading charges against two prominent executives, one from a software company and one from a mining concern. Who Can Invest and How Shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange, Canada's biggest exchange, are available to investors in any part of the world. Shares of many big Canadian companies, from telecommunications giant Nortel Networks Corp., Brampton, Ontario, to transportation concerns Bombardier Inc., Montreal, and Canadian Pacific Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, have long had listings both in Canada and in the U.S. Partly because of this ready access, many U.S. investors hold substantial stakes in Canadian companies, including cable operator Rogers Communications Inc., Toronto; film company Imax Corp., Toronto; and several natural-resources companies, such as gold producer Barrick Gold Corp., Toronto. U.S. investors commonly buy shares directly rather than through mutual funds. Fidelity Canada is devoted to the Canadian stock market, and many natural-resources funds or gold-mining funds in the U.S. have heavy exposure to Canadian companies. One easy way to invest in Canada's stock market is to buy shares of iUnits, which represent an investment in the S&P/TSE 60 Index, launched last year. The iUnits trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange and give investors a stake in 60 of Canada's biggest companies, as measured by market cap. A similar index fund, Webs Canada, trades on the American Stock Exchange in New York. The Upside and Downside Despite the tech upheaval of recent weeks, Canada's stock market is heavily weighted toward technology and communications. Nortel alone, for example, hogs about one-quarter of the S&P/TSE 60. This provides both a risk and an opportunity for investors in the Canadian market, some analysts say. If tech shares hold their ground, there could be solid returns still to come in the market as valuations firm up in banking, natural resources and other areas. If tech stocks crumble further, however, Canada's stock indexes will struggle to hold their gains. For a Bear in Texas, Stocks' Plunge Is Honey but Not Yet Vindication
Content: The Wall Street Journal J Texas Journal T2 English (Copyright (c) 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) After last week's technology-stock crash, one might have guessed champagne corks were popping at the Dallas headquarters of David W. Tice & Associates. No way, says Mr. Tice, one of the nation's most outspoken bears. He has officially declared his office a no-gloating zone. Not that he didn't have reason to be pleased. Thanks to the past month's jitters, Mr. Tice once again is getting his day in the sun. From March 10, the day the Nasdaq Composite Index peaked at an intra-day high of 5132.52, through the end of last week, Mr. Tice's Prudent Bear Fund soared 21.5%, the second-best performance by any U.S. diversified equity mutual fund over that time period, according to Lipper Inc. That's because the $215 million fund he manages is geared primarily toward betting that stock prices will drop, or short selling, which benefits from market downturns. Last week, the fund was up 23.4%, making it the top one-week performer during a stretch when the Nasdaq Composite fell 25.3%. Of course, this has been a long time coming. For years, Mr. Tice's bets against the bullish tide have been dead wrong. That in part explains why he isn't exactly celebrating just yet. And if past investor behavior is any indication, the good times for Prudent Bear holders could be short-lived. Just Monday, for instance, Prudent Bear gave up 4.4% of its value, finishing at $4.33 a share, compared with the Nasdaq Composite's 6.6% gain that day. And yesterday the Nasdaq Composite gained 7.2% to close at 3793.57. In a memo e-mailed to his 23 employees over the weekend, Mr. Tice cautioned his staff not to rub in the recent gains when hobnobbing around town. "I believe I have told you how careful we have to be when the market starts going our way," Mr. Tice wrote. "Now is that time. It should affect how we act with our friends in a bar or at a restaurant or at a hockey game because others will be observing. With the Nasdaq market down more last week than any week in history, it's time to be careful. Lots of bulls have been obnoxious. But we can never celebrate openly." Nor does he feel anywhere near vindicated just yet. After all, despite its swoon, the Nasdaq Composite at Friday's close was still up 32% from a year earlier. Mr. Tice, by comparison, has been publicly sounding alarms about stock-market bubbles since 1994. Indeed, through last week, Prudent Bear had produced an average annual loss of 17% for the previous three years. This means that an investor who plunked $1,000 into Mr. Tice's no-load fund in April 1997 finished last week with only about $570 to show for it. The fund's one-year return, through Friday, was a hair under 5%. "We were so early, it's not like we've been proved right yet," says the 45-year-old Mr. Tice. During the summer of 1998, when the broader market also was in bearish territory, Mr. Tice was warning that a global economic meltdown would send shivers through the U.S. economy, pointing to such warning signs as the Asian financial collapse, economic troubles in Russia, rampant manufacturing overcapacity and sluggish energy prices that were causing pains for some developing nations. Today, his concerns are just as pointed: Americans' credit is overextended. Foreign investors may pull out of U.S. stocks now that there's a chink in the armor. Tech-stock valuations, which he and others believed to be outrageous and unsustainable a few years ago, are even more so today in his view. Inflation is rising, signaling future interest-rate boosts and a weaker U.S. dollar. And in a prolonged bear market, the much-discussed "wealth effect" created by recent market gains could be turned on its head, curbing consumer confidence and spending. At least for the past month, Mr. Tice's short-selling strategy has been a winning one. (In a short sale, an investor bets on falling prices by borrowing shares of stock and immediately selling them, hoping to profit by buying back shares at lower prices at some point in the future.) Among the stocks that fueled Prudent Bear's recent gains: cellular-phone maker Qualcomm, now down 44% from its 52-week high at $118.188; RF Micro Devices, a maker of wireless-communications equipment, off 47% at $97.313; chip manufacturer Rambus, down 68% at $152; and e-commerce reservations booker priceline.com, down 61% at $64. All four, in Mr. Tice's view, still have much further to fall. Qualcomm, for one, still trades for more than 260 times trailing earnings. And priceline.com continues to use what he sees as aggressive revenue-recognition practices; namely, it includes the cost of an airline ticket, for instance, in its own top-line revenue results, as it's collecting the brokering fee for booking a reservation. Priceline contends its accounting is sound because unlike travel agents, it does take ownership of tickets for a short period during the transaction. Mr. Tice last year issued a report critical of accounting practices at Tyco International, sending its stock plunging. Tyco in December disclosed that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an inquiry into its accounting. The company has denied that its accounting was improper and has said it is cooperating with the SEC. Mr. Tice declines to say what other companies his fund currently is shorting, but he does point to several examples of stocks on which he is decidedly bearish. Mr. Tice says he is sour on International Business Machines, currently down 17% from its 52-week high at $115.125. He envisions slowing sales and heightened competition combined with declining profitability from personal-computer sales at IBM. Chase Manhattan, down 20% from its peak at $80.75, could be headed for more declines, he says, partly due to downturns in the value of its venture-capital holdings. And he cautions that storage-systems maker EMC, down 10% from its high at $129.875, remains overvalued at 136 times trailing earnings in an industry also marked by increasing competition and falling product prices. If he is right, Mr. Tice promises, there won't be any crowing. "People don't like to be told `I told you so' when they're losing a lot of money," he says. "History has taught us that excesses in the financial system have to be wrung out. This is just the beginning. It will take a period of years. And it will be very painful. Because of that, it's hard to feel celebratory."  Rough Landing: Kitty Hawk fell 93.6% last week to 28.1 cents a share. Last week the Dallas air-cargo company said it will miss a debt payment, blaming high maintenance costs and slower growth in the first quarter. It is negotiating with lenders and considering selling assets.  Safety Plays: Investors last week ducked into some out-of-favor Texas stocks at the same time that recent highfliers were getting dumped. Service Corp. International, the Houston funeral-home chain, jumped 36.7% last week to $4.188. And inflation concerns sparked a 25.9% rise in Houston-based Battle Mountain Gold, to $2.125. Small-capitalization biotechnology companies like Interleukin Genetics, San Antonio, and Energy Biosystems, The Woodlands, lost more than half their value.  Nose Dive: Dallas-based i2 Technologies fell 43% last week to $78.063, reflecting a sectorwide downturn in business-to-business e-commerce stocks.

OTTAWA (Reuters) -- Some of Canada's best-known birds are set to become extinct -- on the country's bank notes, at least. The loon, beloved denizen of Canada's lakes, will keep its safe nesting place on the back of the dollar coin, commonly known as the "loonie," said an official at the Royal Canadian Mint. But on the nation's bank notes the belted kingfisher, osprey, common loon, snowy owl and Canada goose will soon be gone, victims of a redesign of the country's colorful $5, $10, $20, $50 and $100 bills, the Bank of Canada said. Canada's bills have been bedecked with birds since 1986. They are being redesigned to better prevent counterfeiting, with the new series set for release in 2001, the central bank said. "The new design itself is still being worked on and we're not, for security reasons, in a position to announce a particular content of the design until much closer to 2001," Bank of Canada currency educator Bill Cook said. He said the bank was polling Canadians about their views on what should be pictured on the back of the bills, which previously have portrayed allegorical figures, landscapes and industries, as well as birds in the current series. Depictions of famous Canadians are an option, Mr. Cook said. The front of the blue, purple, green, red and brown bills currently depicts stylized numerals as well as a portrait of either Queen Elizabeth or former Canadian prime ministers. Mr. Cook declined to say whether the portraits, which were also on the previous series of notes, will be kept, but he noted that portraits are found on almost every nation's banknotes because they are engraved and thus difficult to counterfeit. The central bank reportedly tested the popularity of the removal of the Queen's portrait from the bills through polling, and found opinion evenly split -- so the Queen will stay on at least one of the notes. A spokesman for the Royal Canadian Mint, which designs and produces Canada's coin currency, said there are no plans to shoo the loon from the trademark gold-colored dollar coin. "We're not removing the loon," Pierre Morin said.

Reappoint Greenspan Now
Reappoint Greenspan Now
Content: The Wall Street Journal J A22 English (Copyright (c) 1999, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) A week ago the Federal Open Market Committee raised interest rates for the first time in 2 1/2 years. Under different circumstances, this would probably have had a dampening effect, yet the markets rallied sharply, taking comfort in the perception that the Federal Reserve would not raise rates again soon. Commodity prices, led by gold, copper and oil, all jumped significantly, as did the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which closed Friday at a record high before falling 4.12 points yesterday. Whether the Fed was right to raise rates is a matter of legitimate debate. But the reaction of the markets points to the delicate position in which the Fed now finds itself: What it says (or seems to say) is as important to the economy as what it does. This is not a new phenomenon, but two factors have combined to accentuate its significance. First, the surprising duration of the current economic expansion is causing anxiety about how much longer it can last. Second, Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan has come to be seen as the economy's indispensable man, and the prospect that he might depart when his term expires next June is creating uncertainty about the future course of monetary policy. Taken together, this is a potent recipe for economic trouble -- the most effective remedy for which is for President Clinton to reappoint Mr. Greenspan at once to another term. By most indications, the U.S. economy is the picture of health. But there are disquieting signs of danger. The American consumer has become the consumer of first and last resort for the world. With wage and salary income soaring at 6% annually and consumer prices rising at only about 2.5%, the consumer is flush. But even this ample cash flow has not been enough to satisfy consumer spending habits. Households are increasing their spending faster than their incomes are rising, liquidating a portion of their wealth, or going into debt, to finance the difference. In addition, corporate cash flow is no longer covering business investment. The borrowing needs of the private sector have far outstripped both available private-sector saving and the federal budget surplus. The result is an unprecedented private-sector reliance on foreign inflows of capital. Without such inflows, the American private sector could no longer finance its current level of economic activity. This borrowing need is not only large but growing. Last year our net indebtedness to foreigners rose by more than $200 billion. By the end of this year we may see that number approach a $400 billion annual rate. By the end of next year, if the economy does not slow, we will be relying on foreign financing for nearly $600 billion a year. As our borrowing needs grow, so does the price we pay for the money. Even before the Fed acted, the cost to the Treasury of 30-year money had risen 140 basis points from its low last fall. This is not necessarily bad, but it is imprudent. It means that the fate of the private economy is being held hostage to foreign developments. Heightened credit demands in Asia or Europe, or a perceived weakening in the dollar, would have immediate and profound effects on our economy. The Fed must have the full freedom of movement to preempt such a situation. The Fed must also find its way through a variety of confusing crosscurrents in our so-called New Economy. One of the most important is the use of options as a form of employee compensation. Many employers now give employees throughout the company stock options in lieu of significant pay increases. This has the positive effect of increasing the employee's stake in the firm's performance. Employees have no complaints given the recent performance of the equity markets. But the widespread use of options sends a number of confusing signals to decision makers. Options are not counted as "compensation" either in the national income accounts or on the firm's profit-and-loss statement. As such, wage data can suggest that employment costs are contained, when in fact they are growing quite rapidly. Furthermore, corporate profitability can be easily overstated since compensation costs can be paid in "free" money -- promises of corporate stock that appear not to dilute shareholder value. The combined effect is to create the appearance of a benign economic environment underneath which assets and liabilities are becoming increasingly mismatched. The Fed also faces confusing signals on productivity. There are many reasons to believe that we may be understating productivity in some high-technology areas. But we are also not correctly measuring the decline in quality of customer service resulting from labor shortages, downsizing and the increasing use of workers with subpar language, math and social skills. The addition of these new workers to the labor force, while socially very beneficial, imposes a cost that is not counted in the traditional productivity calculation. But the Fed's problems are not only economic. During his most recent congressional testimony, Mr. Greenspan was assailed for daring to raise rates just as the American worker was starting to benefit from the current expansion. Politicians of varied political stripes will increasingly find the Fed an easy target as the campaign season heats up. Should the bond market come to feel that Fed policy is being dictated by political considerations, the economic consequences would be severe. Complicating this still further is the prospect of Mr. Greenspan's departure. In this regard, Mr. Clinton has three options. First, he could choose to nominate someone else. That would send a clear vote of no confidence and is sure to upset the markets. Then too, the chances are slim to none that the Senate would confirm an entirely new nominee of a lame-duck president from the opposite party. Thus, nominating someone other than Mr. Greenspan is both dangerous for the economy and politically futile. Second, Mr. Clinton could announce that the next president should choose the next chairman, leaving Mr. Greenspan to serve as a lame duck. There is some political merit in this, especially since the term as chairman would no longer come up during a presidential election year. But these considerations are far outweighed by the economic risks. Leaving the choice of chairman to the next president would politicize the issue of monetary policy while creating dangerous uncertainties about its future. This is not a recipe for stability. The third option, of course, is to renominate Mr. Greenspan. The only question is when. Waiting until his current term expires would place his confirmation hearings at the height of the political season. In the meantime the markets would be free to speculate about behind the scenes deals between the Fed and the White House, thus eroding the perception of the Fed's independence. It is exactly what the markets, the economy, and the country cannot afford. There is, then, only one thing that Mr. Clinton can do that would both remove monetary policy from politics and alleviate the current uncertainty in markets: renominate Mr. Greenspan now. The combined effect of his reappointment by a Democratic president and his confirmation by a Republican Senate would signal to global markets that American monetary policy has a stable bipartisan basis. It would allow the Fed to concentrate on the difficult task at hand, free of political distraction. And it would leave a legacy worthy of any president.  Mr. Lindsey, a former governor of the Federal Reserve, is a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.
