The Millennium --- Leisure: What Money Can Buy --- One era's luxury is another's squalor; A look at
palaces through the ages
Content: The Wall Street Journal J R36 English (Copyright (c) 1999, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) Sultan Murat III was ruler of his world in the 16th century, enthroned in a white-domed palace with 300 rooms for his wives and concubines and 4,000 stalls for his horses. But when it comes to creature comforts, the Turkish sultan's palace was nothing compared with those of modern millionaires like Leona Helmsley. When she had a mansion built in Arizona, Ms. Helmsley included faucets of 24-karat gold, a glass-walled dining room overlooking a waterfall, a film-projection system that lowers from the ceiling, and an underwater sound system for the swimming pool. What defines luxury has changed drastically over the past 1,000 years. Monarchs and moguls have always had scads of servants to pamper and protect them, but generally were expected to house and feed their retinues in vast compounds. So peace and quiet -- things most middle-class Americans take for granted -- were in short supply. So, too, were comfort and privacy. A powerful, rich person might sit all day on a gilded throne and sleep on silk sheets, but was always on display. Never could the rich experience the total relaxation of modern wage slaves, channel-surfing from their recliners in ratty sweatsuits. Palaces were primitive in other ways, too. Many of the niceties of modern home life were invented in the past two centuries -- not just air conditioning and electric lights and appliances, but also flush toilets and even window screens, for example. So until recently, even the grandest residences tended to be dim, drafty and vulnerable to vermin. But comfort wasn't the goal. Palaces were built to awe, and to last. They were monuments as much as domiciles, works of art and inspiration in a time before mass-media amusements. Here is a look at palatial home life over the past 1,000 years. England Windsor Castle Now a compound covering 13 acres and displaying some of the world's finest artwork, architecture and furnishings, Windsor Castle started as an earthwork-and-timber fortification built by William the Conqueror around 1080 to guard the Thames River. Its layout was simple -- a mound, or "motte," surrounded by a fenced yard, or "bailey." But its site, near a 4,800-acre royal hunting ground and about 20 miles west of London, was considered so favorable, his successors turned it into a permanent residence. Although the residence now has every modern comfort -- along with elaborate plaster carvings, gilded trim, and damask wall and window coverings -- for the first three centuries of its existence it was a humble affair, and life within it was hardly luxurious. There were improvements made during that time. In 1170, Henry II starting replacing the original timber structures with stone. Setting the style for succeeding architects, he had a round stone tower with crenelated battlements built on the raised motte William had created, and added two sets of apartments -- one with a hall to receive his court, another just for his family. Over the next two centuries, his successors added five round towers to the outside wall, expanded the royal apartments, and created a chapel and a great hall for the Knights of the Garter. But it was still a Norman castle -- thick-walled, dark and dank, says Lisa Reilly, associate professor of architectural history at the University of Virginia. The only light came from candles and torches, and though rich tapestries covered the walls and expensive glass was used in some windows, they weren't enough to dispel the constant drafts. Floors were cold, too, because carpets were considered too precious and delicate to throw on the floor -- they were more likely to be used as wall or table coverings. And smoke and smells from meat roasting on spits in the huge fireplaces permeated the air. Roasting meat was one of the better smells in the castle. Baths were infrequent, and even the elite wore clothes a long time before washing them. Built-in latrines jutted out of the wall over the moat, which consequently reeked. People casually let food drop to the rush-strewn floor, where, if not picked up by the resident hounds or falcons, it rotted. "It was pretty gross," says Prof. Reilly. Medieval courts were constantly on the move, so rulers could keep a high profile with their subjects, and they carried their most precious furnishings with them, down to the gold plates and crystal goblets. Entertainments tended to be portable, too, and included hunting, jousting, falconry, cards, dice, chess, needlework and lawn bowling. For all their power, rulers rarely had any time to themselves. Hundreds lived in the castle, and even at bedtime, when the royals retired to their fur-covered featherbed, surrounded by a linen curtain, they weren't alone: Servants bedded down in the same room on trundle beds, alert to any royal whisperings. "The idea of privacy had yet to evolve," Prof. Reilly says. China Imperial Palace The constant threat of barbarian invasion caused Chinese emperors to move their capital a number of times early in the millennium. And although Beijing was the site from the years 1260 to 1368, it wasn't until the capital returned there in the early 15th century that Yong Le, the third Ming emperor, created a permanent imperial residence. Built by some 200,000 laborers, this in time became an 8,886-room complex on a rectangle measuring 3,150 by 2,460 feet. Over the next five centuries, the 180-acre compound was home to 24 successive emperors. Although it was known as the Forbidden City, many servants and tradespeople came and went daily; only 9,000 people resided there full time. Architects used the ancient Chinese philosophy of feng shui -- literally "wind-water," it's the art of arranging buildings and furnishings for good fortune and success -- to lay out the palace and grounds in harmony with nature. Most buildings face south to benefit from sunny yang and counteract harmful yin from the north, such as cold winds, bad spirits and barbarian invaders. Streets run either north-south or east-west. Moats, walls and four gates at the cardinal points -- north, south, east and west -- protected the city from the outside world. The buildings, made from timber, brick, stone and marble, were less than two stories tall, so as not to disturb the spirits of the air. In the inner reaches of the city, ceremonial pavilions and three palaces reserved for the emperor and his wives and concubines were decorated with gilt and carvings of dragons, cranes and other "lucky" beasts. In its early years, the palace probably had translucent paper windows, rather than glass -- and no screens to keep out insects, of course. "They had servants to swat the flies," says Richard Stamps, a professor of Chinese studies at Oakland University in Rochester, Mich. The palaces were constantly warmed and perfumed by braziers in which incense was burned -- a reasonable measure, given that the outer courtyards held livestock, including pigs and sheep, and the emperor's 48 elephants. But conditions weren't as unhygienic as in some Western cities, thanks to a system of crude slot-in-the-ground toilets, septic tanks and waste drains, according to Prof. Stamps. "Farmers would take away the waste and spread it on their fields for fertilizer," he says. Ritual ruled the emperor's day. Typically, he arose each day at 3 a.m. and received visitors or presided over parades and ceremonies nonstop until lunchtime. At noon he dined alone. Because the main kitchens were so far away from the emperor's quarters, his food often arrived cold, prompting one emperor to have a small warming kitchen built near his dining room. But imperial banquets were worse -- tedious affairs for both the emperor, on whom all eyes were riveted, and for the guests, who were expected to bang their heads on the floor whenever the host said anything amusing or even when he was served something to drink. According to "The Forbidden City: Center of Imperial China" by Gilles Beguin and Dominique Morel, an 18th-century priest once complained after attending an imperial banquet: "There are those magnificent meals where a European dies of hunger. The way in which he is forced to sit on the ground on a mat with crossed legs is awkward; neither the wine nor the dishes that are offered are to his taste . . . . One would initially say that it was an idol to whom a sacrifice was going to be made rather than a prince to whom food was being served." The emperor and his retinue enjoyed beautiful, albeit artificial, gardens (trees out of season were sometimes decorated with silk blossoms), numerous temples and shrines, a library and a dozen theaters. But because he spent his days in ceremonies, was often carried on a covered litter called a palanquin and was required to nibble on multicourse meals, the emperor had limited opportunities to exercise -- one reason that the various thrones dotting the complex, made of gold or jade and padded with yellow silk, were exceptionally capacious. Turkey Topkapi Palace The spectacular view continues to be of the confluence of the Golden Horn, the Bosporus Strait and the Sea of Marmara, but Topkapi Palace itself has been been through many transformations. It has been swept over the years by four major fires and endless renovations and expansions. Although Sultan Mehmet the Conqueror moved to Topkapi in 1465, much of the current compound, including the famous harem, was built by Sultan Murat III in the late 1500s. The 54-acre walled compound embodied a new idea for the Ottomans: that the sultan was sacred and should keep his distance from the masses. But though the sultans kept aloof, they hardly lived alone. For the 500 years the Ottoman sultans resided there, it was a swarming place, though exceptionally well-organized. "Even the horses seem to know where they are," wrote a traveler named Tourenfort in 1700. Within the compound's walls, many stone kiosks recall nomadic tents. Most of the buildings are low, with overhanging eaves; they make the palace look as though it is clinging to the side of the cliff. The compound included 10 mosques, 14 baths, and two hospitals, plus an armory, a mint, a school, a circumcision room, a fountain to cleanse the blood from the executioner's ax, various dormitories for servants, and a zoo containing such exotic wild animals as lions and elephants. A series of kitchens served 5,000 full-time residents, who consumed more than 300 sheep or goats and 650 fowl daily, nibbled on a new cheese called feta, and sampled fruits and other delicacies brought in from all over the empire. More than 100 cartloads of wood had to be hauled in daily to feed the kitchen's roaring stoves. In an inner compound, away from the clatter of the kitchens and the bustle of tradesmen who served the palace, 300 warren-like rooms in the well-guarded harem held some 2,000 people -- the sultan's mother, wives, concubines and children. Since many of the occupants spent much of their lives sitting on silk rugs or pillows, windows were placed low, and the rooms were on raised bases to maximize views of the courtyard gardens. The sultan's mother and wives had several apartments, but most concubines slept three or four to a room. The harem surrounded the apartments of the sultan, richly decorated in brocades, murals, stained-glass windows and intricately carved furniture, with many fountains that made it difficult to eavesdrop on his conversations. (Some visitors complained that it was uncomfortable to walk on the Oriental carpets, which were sewn with jewels.) The sultan's domed bedroom was warmed by a bronze fireplace and window shutters inlaid with mother-of-pearl; in the basement was a pool fed by various fountains, which functioned as a cool summer retreat. Beautiful as it was, Topkapi was nevertheless a prison for all who lived there. Sultans did as they pleased, sending rival brothers and sons to the executioner, or banishing them to a life of forced ease in the harem. But even the sultan's life was circumscribed by constant calls to prayer and by idle pursuits such as archery or watching fireworks, according to a Venetian visitor to the court of Murat III in 1585 as described in "Architecture, Ceremonial, and Power: the Topkapi Palace in the 15th and 16th Centuries" by Gulru Necipoglu. "The sultan does not, in my opinion, live so desirable a life," wrote the visitor, "for he stays almost constantly enclosed in his seraglio in the company of eunuchs, boys, dwarfs, mutes and slaves, which seems to me almost as bad as [the company of] women . . . ." Russia Catherine Palace When Peter the Great established his capital in St. Petersburg in 1703, he attracted a number of Italian architects who unleashed a wave of baroque and neoclassical building unrivaled anywhere in Europe. Two of his imperial successors, Elizabeth and Catherine II (the Great), shared his passion for building, and between them erected a number of monumental palaces. One, known in different eras as the Great Palace, the Ekaterinsky Palace or the Catherine Palace, was at Tsarkoe Selo about 25 miles from the city. It was named for Peter the Great's second wife, and Elizabeth's mother, Catherine I. The palace was 978 feet long, with two small wings of about 50 feet each. Almost overpowering in scale, its three-story facade was broken up by a series of balustrades, columns and pediments. The stuccoed walls were turquoise, the columns white, and all the exterior ornamentation and statues were gilded. (European contemporaries scoffed at the glittering effect the original architects created -- an English traveler called it "most tawdry" -- and Catherine II had most of the gilding removed after Elizabeth died.) Meant to impress rather than to repel invaders, the palace had a purely decorative drawbridge and parklike grounds ringed only with iron fences and canals. The parks contained a number of art galleries and pavilions, as well as a theater, cold baths, a church and an orangery. Catherine II used the palace as her main summer residence, and despite her distaste for gilding, spared little expense ornamenting her interiors in the latest neoclassical style. In her private apartments, walls were covered with lapis lazuli and damask silk, and parquet floors were inlaid with mother-of-pearl. The walls of her own bedroom were made of milky-white glass, punctuated by lilac-colored glass columns, mirrors and Wedgwood medallions. The palace sported some state-of-the-art conveniences, such as ceramic-tile-covered wood-burning stoves that were both more efficient and less smoky than traditional open fireplaces, and private toilets. But there was still no running water -- for either the toilets or the rest of the palace -- and food was brought in from a separate building by serfs. Still, imperial life was more relaxed for Catherine II than it had been for earlier rulers, in Russia and elsewhere. Though an estimated 400 people lived in the palace when the court was in residence, many servants lived outside the palace grounds (which covered 1,483 acres and included 100 buildings), thus reducing the number of prying eyes. And livestock was banished from the parks, cutting down on noise and filth. Informal entertainments such as outdoor concerts and picnics were gaining in popularity. These were hardly rustic affairs, though: According to William Craft Brumfield, professor of Russian studies at Tulane University in New Orleans, servants set tables on the lower levels of the outdoor pavilions and then winched them up to the elite guests on the upper levels, so as not to disturb the guests' contemplation of nature. Catherine II considered herself an enlightened ruler and adopted many new ideas, such as the notion of privacy -- at least for herself. Indeed, she even placed her own apartments at the opposite end of the immense palace from those of her son, the Grand Duke Paul. "Nothing was allowed to intrude on her, not even her children," says Prof. Brumfield. U.S. Biltmore Estate By the late 19th century, American tycoons were living as lavishly as monarchs. One who decided to build a country palace worthy of any prince was George Washington Vanderbilt, grandson of industrialist Cornelius Vanderbilt. Though now open to the public, the estate is still in family hands. A linguist, musician and patron of the arts, George Vanderbilt built his 250-room mansion on 125,000 acres overlooking the Blue Ridge Mountains. (The estate today is a mere 8,000 acres.) Richard Morris Hunt, a pre-eminent architect, designed the house to look like a castle from the Loire Valley, and Frederick Law Olmsted, the famous landscape architect, created formal and informal gardens on 250 acres. Mr. Vanderbilt had a special railroad spur built to deliver the tons of Indiana limestone and other materials needed at the construction site, as well as the massive collection of antiques, artwork and Oriental carpets used to furnish the completed house. Begun in 1890 and finished five years later, the mansion was probably the most innovative residence of its day. It used some of Thomas Edison's first light bulbs, and had other new electrical wonders, such as two elevators, a fire-alarm system, a rotisserie, refrigeration systems, and call boxes for servants. It also sported such state-of-the-art features as 10 telephones and central heating powered by a huge steam furnace. Air conditioning hadn't yet been developed, but Biltmore had electric fans, a new invention. The 43 bathrooms provided hot water on demand, a remarkable innovation. Biltmore was also a prototype of what has now become a common sight in wealthy neighborhoods: the pleasure palace. For recreation, there was an indoor swimming pool, billiard room, bowling alley and gymnasium. For entertaining, there was a banquet hall that seated 64 guests, a conservatory filled with tropical flowers, a library of 23,000 books, and a number of sitting rooms filled with paintings by such artists as Albrecht Durer, John Singer Sargent and Pierre Auguste Renoir. As much as possible, the estate was set up to be self-sufficient, growing many of its own vegetables and raising cattle to provide beef and dairy products. And while visitors to palaces in previous centuries might have had to endure the sights and smells of various support systems, at Biltmore such things were kept hidden or at a distance. Even the three kitchens and the laundry were sequestered on a lower level, where guests were unlikely to stumble upon them. The protocol of the era precluded the sort of dress-down comfort modern moguls favor; everyone at Biltmore was expected to wear elegant gowns or black tie to dinner and to behave with decorum even when at play. But in every other way, Biltmore's owner achieved what royalty couldn't, even over the course of 1,000 years -- a paradise free of both the trappings of state and the unsettling view of the workers and machinery that made all the luxuries possible. Pauline Merrill, a guest at Biltmore in 1905, summed up her visit in terms that have, in effect, become today's standard for luxury living: "Absolutely everything unpleasant has been eliminated." The 20th-Century Ideal Since Biltmore's time, a new era has dawned: In the 20th century, most in-home luxuries quickly have become everyday conveniences for the masses. Not until 1913 was the first residential air-conditioning system installed: Industrialist Charles Gates (no relation to Bill) had it put in his Minneapolis mansion. Unfortunately, he died before he ever used it, and air conditioning in homes didn't really take off until the 1950s. Today, though, this once unheard-of luxury is an affordable amenity in much of the developed world. Ditto for a whole array of creature comforts. Electric vacuum cleaners, refrigerators, washing machines, clothes dryers, dishwashers, color television -- all dream products just a few generations ago -- have become inexpensive and democratized, thanks to improved technology and mass production. For the first decade or so after color television was introduced in the 1950s, only the well-to-do had the pocket money to splurge on such an extravagance. Nowadays, even many households of modest means own several. Much the same goes for personal computers -- except that the time from when they were introduced to when they became commonplace in homes narrowed to a mere decade. Whirlpool baths, invented by Roy Jacuzzi in 1968, were rarely found anywhere but millionaires' mansions as recently as the late 1980s; now they're upgrades in tract houses. Indeed, the proliferation of luxury products has blurred class barriers. "Whatever other problems we now have, one of the saving graces has been the elimination of profound differences between the rich and the poor," writes Ruth Schwartz Cowan, author of "More Work for Mother." So, what does it take now to have a luxury home the rest of us can only dream about? Well, how about a 5,000-square-foot glass orchid conservatory, like the one former Alamo Rent-A-Car Inc. Chairman Michael S. Egan installed off the master bedroom of his Fort Lauderdale, Fla., home? Or maybe a screening room, manmade lake and boathouse, as in the Miami mansion renovated by movie star Sylvester Stallone? And then there's the main pad of His Majesty Sultan Haji Hassanal Bolkiah of Brunei, a palace with 1,788 rooms (including a banquet room that seats 500), a garage for 150 Rolls-Royces and air-conditioned stalls for 200 ponies. But for the very latest, 21st-century features, even these mansions pale in comparison with the $53.4 million underground home built by -- who else? -- Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates in Redmond, Wash. His estate has all the standard luxuries, as it were, including a theater, a big pool, a trampoline room, an arcade and a dock for water skiing. But thanks to dozens of powerful PCs, it's also programmed to please: Residents or guests can wear special lapel pins, encoded with their particular tastes, that change the electronic artwork "hanging" on walls, control the music and adjust the temperature and lighting to their tastes as they move from room to room.
